newsitem.title: USA: Sick U.S. veterans gain access to clinical trials.
newsitem.headline: Sick U.S. veterans gain access to clinical trials.

text.p: U.S. military veterans can now get easier access to clinical trials of cancer treatments, health officials said on Monday.

Under an agreement that went into effect this month between the National Cancer Institute (NCI) and the Department of Veterans Affairs, more veterans will be able to enter NCI-sponsored clinical trials, which in some cases will mean access to promising new therapies.
"It means greater access to the full range of promising new treatments for cancer," said Dr. Kenneth Kizer, the VA's undersecretary for health.
NCI and VA officials said the agreement would also pave the way for more trials to be carried out in VA medical facilities.

This comes at a time when some traditional academic health centres have cited greater difficulties in running clinical trials because of the cost-cutting pressures of managed care and the overall economic pressures on the health industry.
The agreement with the VA covers prevention, diagnostic and all three phases of treatment trials -- the early tests of new approaches as well as the larger "phase 3" trials that compare treatments.
"Developing an expanded pool of VA cancer researchers will strengthen our clinical research programme across the board," said Dr. Robert Wittes, director of the NCI's division of cancer treatment.
